title: 115_s946
content: The Act titled "Veterans Treatment Court Improvement Act of 2018" allows the Department of Veterans Affairs to hire additional Veterans Justice Outreach Specialists. The "Veterans Treatment Court Improvement Act of 2018" mandates the hiring of at least 50 Veterans Justice Outreach Specialists by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs within a year. These specialists will work in veterans treatment courts or other veteran-focused courts and must meet Department hiring guidelines. The "Veterans Treatment Court Improvement Act of 2018" requires the Department of Veterans Affairs to employ a minimum number of Veterans Justice Outreach Specialists, ensuring that each eligible medical center follows placement guidelines for these specialists. The "Veterans Treatment Court Improvement Act of 2018" mandates the placement of Veterans Justice Outreach Specialists within local criminal justice systems to work with justice-involved veterans and be affiliated with veterans treatment courts. The Secretary must prioritize placement. The Secretary must prioritize placing Veterans Justice Outreach Specialists at VA medical centers affiliated with veterans treatment courts, especially those not fully staffed. The Secretary is also required to provide periodic reports on the implementation of this Act. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a report to Congress annually on the implementation of the Veterans Justice Outreach Program. The report should include the status of hiring Veterans Justice Outreach Specialists and the total number hired. The report to Congress must include the total number of Veterans Justice Outreach Specialists assigned to each participating Department of Veterans Affairs medical center, disaggregated by center. It should also detail the number of eligible centers seeking placement of a specialist and how many specialists each center sought. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress on the implementation and effectiveness of the Veterans Justice Outreach Program within two years of the Act's enactment. The report will include the total number of justice-involved veterans served by Outreach Specialists and the number of medical centers seeking placement of a specialist. The report on the Veterans Justice Outreach Program will assess the Secretary's obligations, the number of veterans served by Outreach Specialists, and identify subgroups of veterans who underutilize services. Authorization of Appropriations: The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is authorized to receive $5,500,000 annually from 2018 to 2028 for the Veterans Justice Outreach Program. The Secretary must also propose cost-saving measures to offset these appropriations. In this section, definitions are provided for terms related to justice teams, justice-involved veterans, and the local criminal justice system. The term "justice team" refers to a group of individuals assisting justice-involved veterans in specialized courts. A "justice-involved veteran" is defined as a veteran with recent involvement in the criminal justice system, and the "local criminal justice system" includes law enforcement, jails, prisons, and courts. The Veterans Justice Outreach Program identifies justice-involved veterans and provides access to VA services. A Veterans Justice Outreach Specialist serves as a liaison between the VA and the local criminal justice system for veterans. Veterans Treatment Court is a court participating in a specialized program for veterans. The bill was passed by the Senate on February 15, 2018.
